Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I guess it is like having a diverse group of people in the same general area. what benefits does that create?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unlike in the bitcoin world where the bitcoin maximalists calls all altcoins as scams (creating a hostile and combative environment), I believe that all KMD based projects can be an asset to the entire ecosystem. Of course, some will revert to the hostile ways and not contribute anything at all, but so far we are seeing the vast majority of projects helping each other out as they can. The spirit of cooperation the KMD ecosystem has is quite a wonderful thing and of course without it, it wouldnt be a thriving ecosystem, but rather a scorched earth battlefield that we see in many parts of crypto

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just look at all the tipbot rain that is happening

Author: Patziggy#9371
Content: That's incredible! Thank you for taking the time to explain this in such a succinct way. It sounds like this approach is maximizing the benefit from comparative advantage and enforces a culture of generalized mutual reciprocity. I've definitely noticed just how positive and cooperative the vast majority of people are in this ecosystem and this information helps to demonstrate why.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we dont have any official guidelines about this, it is just a natural outcome of the tremendous people in the community

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even people not directly involved with any specific coin, might one day have an idea, the next day someone else does a test using that idea, then one thing leads to another and we get PIRATE

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: spontaneous coin creation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so while other projects aim to raise lots of money to attempt to solve a single specific problem and then spend months or years maybe solving it or not, KMD likely already has something that can implement whatever the funding was raised for and it just takes a few people with the initiative to pull it all together

Author: Patziggy#9371
Content:
What a wonderful example of spontaneous order! Having observed the Komodo ecosystem for a while now it really seems (from a non-technical perspective) that innovation is ballooning in a seemingly exponential way. 

When you describe these technical advances made by runtime forks as "coming back" and "made available", are certain advances made compulsory for future runtime forks due to their advantageous nature, or does individual runtime fork customizability take precedent?

Author: Patziggy#9371
Content: I hope my phrasing there is accurate (or at least clear d:). Thanks again for sharing such helpful information üòÑ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at the source code level a runtime fork can become a source code fork

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then when the source code is merged back, it can be a runtime fork again

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the non-core GUI also would directly or indirectly apply

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: open source

Author: Patziggy#9371
Content:
That's fascinating; I feel like I'm always playing catch up with the excellent information you and the rest of the team provide (a good problem to have). Going to take this new knowledge and apply it to future research about the ecosystem! :Komodo: 

Looking forward to contributing in what ways I can \o/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: thanks for your support!

Content: it's confusing, because Sapling is not activated yet, but the code is there, I guess you can play with regtest and testnets until it goes active

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @Patziggy I forgot a very obvious direct benefit!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: whenever any runtime fork convinces a user to install agama to run that coin, then the user is able to run all the other coins with the same agama

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @grewalsatinder I deal with that stuff too, getting stuck on one problem. Debugging experience is more valuable than knowing any one language or library, imho. James says he spend *half* his time debugging

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: clearly identifying the exact bug, breaking it into small bugs, and fix small things until the big thing is fixed, is the general algorithm. But applying it different places takes some creativity + experimentation, like "I know this is crazy and it shouldn't work or do anything but what happens if I do ...." is the real fun/challenge

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: also, work on different things to prevent burnout + frustration, don't bang your head on the same thing for too long if you aren't making progress

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: like this `getchaintips` coredump in KMD I am trying to understand, I keep coming back to it with new ideas, after hacking on other stuff

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: explaining the problem to somebody else, even your imaginary friend, by writing a detailed document, often makes you think of something new

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: @dukeleto wise words. yes, getting your point mate üôÇ üëç

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: A lot of the time, just talking about something with @Alright  or one of the many countless others I have collaberated with over my time here, a solution becomes apparent.. a good team helps too.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: sometimes I write very detailed Github Issues or Pull Requests, even if it's unnecessary, kind of like a book report for my future self, for when I have forgotten all the details

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content:
And yes .. approachin something without knowing what your doing can help too ... ü§î

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it helps the current you really understand and the future you remember wtf you were doing and why

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @blackjok3r not being afraid to fail is very valuable

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: failing is te only way to learn.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: "fail fast and often" is good advice for startups and coders

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `cut: stdin: Illegal byte sequence` is a pretty awesome error. cut don't like arbitrary binary data up in it's files

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am so deep down a hole named `getchaintips`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```~/git/komodo/src dev *$%= )$ gdh
diff --git a/src/rpcblockchain.cpp b/src/rpcblockchain.cpp
index e9cf54bb4..a5537f375 100644
--- a/src/rpcblockchain.cpp
+++ b/src/rpcblockchain.cpp
@@ -1370,6 +1370,7 @@ struct CompareBlocksByHeight
         /* Make sure that unequal blocks with the same height do not compare
            equal. Use the pointers themselves to make a distinction. */

+        fprintf(stderr,"%d,%d,%s,%s\n", a->nHeight, b->nHeight, a->GetBlockHash().ToString(), b->GetBlockHash().ToString());
         if (a->nHeight != b->nHeight)
           return (a->nHeight > b->nHeight);```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you would think block heights + hashes would be printed, but you would be wrong, i get heights and garbage data

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the RPC compares just under 4000 different blocks, and then coredumps

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: deeeeeeep in boost land, which uses this comparator

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```
frame #0: 0x00000001001c68c4 komodod`std::pair<std::_Rb_tree_iterator<CBlockIndex const*>, bool> std::_Rb_tree<CBlockIndex const*, CBlockIndex const*, std::_Identity<CBlockIndex const*>, CompareBlocksByHeight, std::allocator<CBlockIndex const*> >::_M_insert_unique<CBlockIndex const*>(this=0x000070000639e240, __v=0x000070000639e5d0) at stl_tree.h:1833```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: inserting into a std::set causing a core dump, is that memory corruption or could it be something else?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: full gist of full backtrace is here if you are into that kind of thing: https://gist.github.com/leto/467977023e3357a626fa47a941977961

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `insert_unique` into a std::pair seems to be the boost thing that fails
